claim: Men can prevent premature baldness by shaving their head to avoid it.

supporting.text: Shaving the head does not prevent the biological processes that cause baldness, such as androgenetic alopecia.

attacks.text: Shaving the head does not prevent the biological processes that cause baldness, such as androgenetic alopecia.
Shaving the head can create the illusion of preventing baldness by removing visible signs of hair thinning.
The illusion does not address the underlying cause of baldness, which continues regardless of shaving.
Some studies suggest scalp stimulation from shaving may temporarily improve blood circulation, potentially slowing hair loss.
The effect of scalp stimulation on hair loss is minimal and not scientifically proven to prevent baldness.

supporting.text: Baldness is primarily caused by genetic and hormonal factors, which are not affected by shaving the head.

attacks.text: Baldness is primarily caused by genetic and hormonal factors, which are not affected by shaving the head.
Shaving the head can create the illusion of preventing baldness by removing thinning hair before it becomes noticeable.
The illusion does not address the underlying genetic or hormonal causes of baldness, making it a temporary and superficial solution.
Some studies suggest that scalp massages or treatments applied after shaving might slow hair loss, indirectly linking shaving to prevention.
These studies are inconclusive and lack large-scale replication, making their findings unreliable for general recommendations.

supporting.text: Shaving the head only removes visible hair and does not address the underlying causes of hair loss.

attacks.text: Shaving the head only removes visible hair and does not address the underlying causes of hair loss.
Shaving the head can create the illusion of thicker hair when it regrows, which may psychologically benefit individuals experiencing hair loss.
The illusion of thicker hair is temporary and does not prevent the progression of underlying conditions like androgenetic alopecia.
Shaving the head can reduce the visibility of thinning hair, making baldness less noticeable and thus 'preventing' its premature appearance socially.
Social perception does not equate to biological prevention; the actual hair loss process continues unaffected.

supporting.text: Premature baldness is a result of hair follicle miniaturization, which continues regardless of whether the head is shaved.

attacks.text: Premature baldness is a result of hair follicle miniaturization, which continues regardless of whether the head is shaved.
Shaving the head can reduce stress on hair follicles, potentially slowing down the miniaturization process.
There is no scientific evidence that shaving reduces stress on hair follicles or affects miniaturization.
Shaving the head creates the illusion of thicker hair, which can psychologically reduce perceived baldness.
Psychological effects do not address the underlying biological process of hair follicle miniaturization.

supporting.text: Medical treatments like minoxidil or finasteride are proven to slow or prevent baldness, unlike shaving.

attacks.text: Medical treatments like minoxidil or finasteride are proven to slow or prevent baldness, unlike shaving.
Shaving the head can create the illusion of preventing baldness by removing visible hair loss, but it does not address the underlying causes.
Even with medical treatments, baldness may progress in some individuals due to genetic factors, making shaving a viable cosmetic alternative.
Shaving does not affect hair follicles or hormonal processes, which are the primary factors in baldness.
Shaving may reduce scalp irritation and improve the effectiveness of topical treatments like minoxidil.
